title: Broadcom Says Core Chip Business Has Bottomed Out
text:
Broadcom Inc., AVGO 0.86% hard hit by U.S.-China trade tensions and export restrictions to Huawei Technologies Co., on Thursday said it believes its core semiconductor business has bottomed out but isn’t quite in recovery mode yet.

Chief Executive Hock Tan, speaking during a conference call with analysts, said he is confident the bottom of the cycle has been reached but said it is too early to speak of a turnaround.

“We are managing the business with an expectation that we will continue to operate in a very low-growth, uncertain macro environment for the foreseeable future,” Mr. Tan said.

Broadcom maintained a revenue target of $22.5 billion for the year ending Nov. 3, including $17.5 billion from semiconductor solutions and $5 billion from infrastructure software.

Huawei, blacklisted by the U.S. over national-security concerns, accounted for around $900 million, or 4.3%, of revenue last year.

Apple Inc. is Broadcom’s largest customer and accounted for about one-quarter of revenue last year.

Mr. Tan, who built Broadcom through a series of bold acquisitions, last month struck a roughly $10.7 billion deal to buy Symantec Corp.’s enterprise security business. The deal, along with the 2017 acquisition of Brocade Communications Systems Inc. and the 2018 acquisition of CA Technologies, are part of a big—and costly—bet around infrastructure software.

On Thursday, Broadcom executives said the company would maintain its dividend policy of paying investors half of its free cash flow from the previous fiscal year but would focus on paying down debt, rather than repurchase shares.

“Especially in light of the week macro environment we are seeing today,” Chief Financial Officer Thomas Krause said, “we are conscious of the risk that our levered balance sheet creates and are very focused on managing those risks.”

Through Aug. 4, when Broadcom’s third quarter ended, the company had generated about $6.88 billion in free cash flow, the money left after paying expenses. Broadcom expects it to reach about $9 billion by year-end, up from $8.25 billion a year earlier.

The company, based in Silicon Valley, reported third-quarter profit dropped to $715 million, or $1.71 a share, from $1.2 billion, or $2.71 a share, in the same period a year earlier as operating expenses surged 69% to $2.17 billion. Profit from continuing operations rose to $5.16 a share from $4.98 a share a year earlier.

Net revenue rose 9% to $5.52 billion.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected a profit of $1.21 a share, or $5.13 as adjusted, on $5.52 billion in revenue.

Gross profit margin improved to 55% from 51.7% a year earlier.

It was Broadcom’s first financial report since Europe’s top anticompetition regulator opened an investigation into the company, alleging Broadcom wielded its dominance of the market for chips used in modems and television set-top boxes to curtail competition. The European Commission also said it would take the rare step of ordering the company to immediately halt certain practices that it says are anticompetitive, the first time European Union competition authorities have imposed such interim measures in 18 years.

Broadcom has defended its business practices and said it doesn’t expect any material impact from the investigation.

Broadcom’s stock, which has been trading near record levels, closed Thursday at $300.58, up 0.9% for the day.

Write to Maria Armental at maria.armental@wsj.com
